poem:
**Leaning into Christmas**

In the bare chill of  
early December—  
the streetlights splay  
Christmas songs—  
a red sweater, too jolly,  
blankets the chill.  
  
Fir needles  
make their quiet  
home, while  
trees glow, not  
in spite,  
but because of  
plain desire;  
the early flutter  
of tinseled hearts  
stirring, unreserved,  
in the waning light.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Are you leaning into Christmas this year? We’d like to hear from you Are you leaning in to Christmas this year, determined to make the most of the festive season? Perhaps you put your Christmas tree up earlier than usual? Or, for the first time in years? Maybe you’re embracing Christmas jumper wearing with unusual zeal? Or perhaps you’re listening to Christmas songs earlier than usual? Maybe you’re making more effort to enjoy time with". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
